Name: Western Rivers Conservancy
Description: Western Rivers Conservancy buys land along the West’s finest rivers and streams to conserve habitat for fish and wildlife, protect key sources of cold water and provide public access for all to enjoy.

Name: Columbia Land Trust
Description: Conserve and care for the vital lands, waters, and wildlife of the Columbia River region through sound science and strong relationships.
Ways to Get Involved: Backyard Program, Corporate Partnership, Donate, Donate Land, Volunteer

Name: Cascade Forest Conservancy
Description: the cascade forest conservancy protects and sustains the forests, streams, wildlife, and communities in the heart of the cascades through conservation, education, and advocacy.

Name: The Lower Columbia Estuary Partnership
Description:
The Lower Columbia Estuary Partnership is a non-profit, a National Estuary Program, and a collection of dedicated scientists, educators, and community members who are passionate about the Columbia River.
We focus on the lower 146 miles of the Columbia River, from Bonneville Dam to the Pacific Ocean, including the tidally influenced portions of tributaries in that area. The watershed includes 28 cities, nine counties, and 45 school districts within the states of Oregon and Washington.

Name: Columbia River Fish and Wildlife Conservation Office
Description: It is the mission of the Columbia River Fish and Wildlife Conservation Office (CRFWCO) to assist in determining the status of imperiled natural stocks, to evaluate management measures for recovery and assist in the recovery of these stocks, and to prevent future listings

Name: Columbia Riverkeeper
Description: It is the mission of the Columbia River Fish and Wildlife Conservation Office (CRFWCO) to assist in determining the status of imperiled natural stocks, to evaluate management measures for recovery and assist in the recovery of these stocks, and to prevent future listings
Ways to Get Involved: Attend Events, Donate, Sign Petitions, Volunteer

Name: Conservation NW
Description: We protect, connect and restore wildlands and wildlife from the Washington Coast to the British Columbia Rockies.
Ways to Get Involved: Corporate Partnership, Donate, Donate Land, Volunteer

Name: https://www.solveoregon.org/
Description: SOLVE is an environmental nonprofit that began as a grassroots initiative and has grown into a nationally recognized model for volunteer-driven stewardship. Each year, SOLVE mobilizes thousands of volunteers across Oregon and Southwest Washington to clean and restore neighborhoods and natural areas, fostering a culture of environmental care and community pride.

Name: Trust for Public Land
Description:
We Believe Everyone Should Have Access to the Outdoors
We create parks and protect land for people, ensuring healthy, livable communities for generations to come.

Name: Oregon Environmental Council
Description: Oregon Environmental Council champions equitable, innovative, and collaborative solutions to Oregon’s environmental challenges for today and future generations.

Name: Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife
Description: Protecting and enhancing Oregon’s fish and wildlife, and the habitats they use, for the use and enjoyment of present and future generations is at the heart of what we do.

Name: Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife
Description: The Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife is dedicated to preserving, protecting, and perpetuating the state’s fish, wildlife, and ecosystems while providing sustainable fish and wildlife recreational and commercial opportunities.

Name: The Sierra Club
Description: The Sierra Club is the most enduring and influential grassroots environmental organization in the United States. We amplify the power of our millions of members and supporters to defend everyone’s right to a healthy world.
Ways to Get Involved: Attend Events, Donate, Sign Petitions, Volunteer

Name: Global Alliance for the Rights of Nature
Description: Our members are a diverse network of scientists, attorneys, economists, indigenous leaders, authors, spiritual leaders, business leaders, politicians, actors, homemakers, students, activists: people from all walks of life who are looking to transform our human relationship with our planet.
